questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the longest muscle in the body?
questions.explanation:
The sartorius muscle is the longest muscle in the body. It originates from the anterior superior iliac spine and inserts into the superior aspect of the 
medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity (joins gracilis and semitendinosus at the 
pes anserinus). It flexes and laterally rotates the hip joint and flexes the knee and is innervated by the femoral 
nerve (L2, L3, and L4).

questions.question: Question 2: The gluteus maximus muscle is attached to:
questions.explanation:
The gluteus maximus muscle is attached to the iliotibial tract of the fascia lata. Origin: • Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium, posterior to posterior gluteal line • Posterior superior iliac spine • Posterior aspect of sacrum and coccyx • Sacrotuberous ligament. Insertion - It is inserted mainly in fascia lata at the iliotibial band and also into the gluteal 
tuberosity on the posterior femoral surface. Action: • Major extensor of hip joint • Lateral rotation of hip joint • Active in powerful abduction of thigh 1068 
Sold by @itachibot Arterial Supply - Inferior and superior gluteal arteries and the first perforating branch of the 
profunda femoris artery. Nerve Supply- Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1 and S2).

questions.question:
Question 3: A boy with a history of a fall from a tree presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his feet. 
Which of the following structures are involved? 1060 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The structure involved in causing lurching gait in the child is gluteus medius (marked as 2). The gluteus medius originates from the outer surface of the ilium between the anterior and 
posterior gluteal lines. Insertion of the muscle is at the lateral surface of the greater trochanter. It 
is supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip joint. Mechanism of actions of 
gluteus medius and minimus: • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on 
the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action 
results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in 
the upright position. • The actions of these muscles are affected when there is an injury to the superior gluteal nerve, 
neck of the femur, or loss of normal angulation of the shaft of the femur. This occurs in conditions 
like paralysis of the glutei, developmental dysplasia of the hip, etc. • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported 
(normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb. This leads to a positive 
Trendelenburg's sign with a characteristic lurching gait - the patient lurches towards the affected 
side with contralateral pelvis drop. 1069 
Sold by @itachibot Other options 1 - Gluteus maximus - involved in the extension of flexed thigh, abduction (only upper fibres), and 
lateral rotation at the hip joint. Insertion is at the iliotibial tract. 3 - Piriformis - involved in lateral rotation and assists abduction at the hip joint. It is inserted into 
the medial side of greater trochanter of the femur. Entrapment of the sciatic nerve in the 
piriformis can lead to piriformis syndrome. 4 - Sciatic nerve - The nerve passes over the obturator internus, gemellus superior, gemellus 
inferior and quadratus femoris. It supplies knee flexors and muscles below the knee. Paralysis of 
this nerve results in flail foot and severe difficulty in walking.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 50-year-old woman underwent total hip replacement surgery. During the procedure, the 
surgeon accidentally severed a nerve. Post-operatively, the patient had a gluteus maximus 
lurch and wasting of the muscle. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.explanation:
1070 
Sold by @itachibot In the given clinical scenario, the inferior gluteal nerve is likely to be injured. The gluteus maximus is innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve. Injury to the nerve causes 
atrophy of the muscle causing weakness in the extension of the thigh. The patients typically have a 
gluteus maximus lurch. The gluteus maximus may be tested by extension of the hip against resistance, in the supine or 
prone position.

questions.question:
Question 5: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image 
below.
questions.explanation:
The image shows the posterior surface of the femur, and the structure marked is gluteal 
tuberosity, to which the gluteus maximus muscle is attached. It causes extension and lateral 
rotation at the hip joint. The femur can be divided into: • The proximal femur - Consists of the head, neck, greater and lesser trochanters. The 
intertrochanteric line is present on the anterior surface at the junction of the neck and shaft of the 
femur while the intertrochanteric crest is present on the posterior surface. • The shaft of the femur - Consists of linea aspera (bony crest present on the posterior surface), 
gluteal tuberosity, and pectineal line • The distal femur - Consists of the medial condyle, lateral condyle, intercondylar fossa, and 
patellar surface 1071 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows attachments of various muscles over the posterior surface of the right 
femur. Gluteus maximus muscle: Origin: • Posterior aspect of the dorsal ilium, posterior to the posterior gluteal line • Posterior superior iliac spine • Posterior aspect of sacrum and coccyx • Sacrotuberous ligament. Insertion - It is inserted mainly in fascia lata at the iliotibial band and also into the gluteal 
tuberosity on the posterior femoral surface. Action: 1072 
Sold by @itachibot • Major extensor of the hip joint • Lateral rotation of the hip joint • Active in powerful abduction of the thigh Arterial Supply - Inferior and superior gluteal arteries and the first perforating branch of the 
profunda femoris artery. Nerve Supply- Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1 and S2).

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following muscles is attached to the lateral surface of the greater trochanter?
questions.explanation:
The gluteus medius muscle is attached to the lateral surface of the greater trochanter. • Greater trochanter: It is a large and quadrangular projection arising from the junction of the 
neck and shaft of the femur. Muscles inserted into it are - • Gluteus minimus • Gluteus medius • Piriformis • Common tendon of obturator internus and gamelli. • Lesser trochanter: It is a conical projection of the shaft present posteromedially. Muscles 
inserted to it are iliacus and psoas major Surface marking: Greater trochanter lies inferior to the midpoint of the iliac crest and at the level 
of the horizontal plane passing through the pubic tubercle. 1073 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: Iliotibial tract receives the insertion of which of the following muscles?
questions.explanation:
The iliotibial tract receives the insertion of tensor fasciae latae. The iliotibial tract is the modification of the deep fascia of the thigh. The proximal end gives 
attachment to the tensor fascia lata and gluteus maximus. The distal end is attached to Gerdy’s 
tubercle present on the lateral condyle of the tibia.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following muscles is a powerful abductor of hip joint?
questions.explanation:
The powerful abductor of hip joint is the gluteus medius. Abduction is assisted by the following muscles: 1074 
Sold by @itachibot • Gluteus minimus • Tensor fascia lata • Piriformis • Sartorius Adduction of the hip joint is mainly caused by • Adductor longus • Adductor brevis • Adductor magnus • Gracilis Flexion of the hip joint is caused by: 1075 
Sold by @itachibot • Psoas major • Iliacus • Rectus femoris • Assisted by: • Pectineus • Tensor fascia lata • Sartorius Extension of the hip joint is caused by: • Gluteus maximus • Biceps femoris • Semitendinosus • Semimembranosus (hamstrings) • Adductor magnus • Assisted by - posterior fibers of gluteus medius

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following muscles causes external rotation of the hip joint?
questions.explanation:
The external rotation of the hip joint is caused by the following muscles: • Gluteus maximus • Obturator internus • Superior and inferior gemelli • Quadratus femoris 1076 
Sold by @itachibot • Piriformis • Assisted by • Obturator externus • Sartorius Internal rotation of the hip joint is caused by the following muscles: • Gluteus medius • Gluteus minimus • Tensor fascia lata • Adductor muscles 1077 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: The posterior femoral muscles are innervated by which nerve?
questions.explanation:
The posterior femoral muscles (hamstring muscles) are innervated by the sciatic nerve. • Semitendinosus, semimembranosus, and the long head of biceps femoris are innervated by tibial 
division of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, and S2) • The short head of biceps femoris is innervated by the common peroneal division of the sciatic 
nerve.

questions.question: Question 11: All of the the following muscles are attached to the ischial tuberosity except:
questions.explanation:
The short head of the biceps femoris is not attached to the ischial tuberosity. It is attached to the 
lateral lip of the linea aspera, lateral supracondylar ridge of the femur, and the lateral 
intermuscular septum of the thigh. 1078 
Sold by @itachibot The ischial tuberosity is broadly divided into upper and lower areas: • The upper area is further subdivided into a superolateral part for the semimembranosus and 
an inferomedial part for the long head of the biceps femoris and the semitendinosus. • The lower area is subdivided by an irregular vertical ridge, into lateral and medial areas. The 
larger lateral area is for the adductor magnus. The smaller medial area is covered by adipose 
tissue, which usually contains the sciatic bursa of the gluteus maximus, which supports the body 
in sitting.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 40-year-old woman presented with severe pain in the buttocks extending down the back of 
the right leg. MRI revealed inflammation of the piriformis muscle. Entrapment of which of 
the following nerves is likely to cause the given condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features are suggestive of piriformis syndrome, which occurs due to the entrapment of 
the sciatic nerve. It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs, or applying firm pressure 
directly over the piriformis muscle. Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the 
buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve. 1079 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: An Indian fast bowler suffered a hamstring injury while practicing due to which he was 
dropped out of the team. Which of the following muscle is not likely to be injured?
questions.explanation:
The sartorius muscle is not a part of hamstring muscles. Hamstring muscles are present in the posterior compartment of the thigh and include 
semimembranosus, semitendinosus, and biceps femoris. They cause the flexion of the knee joint and extension of the hip joint. In addition to this, 
semimembranosus and semitendinosus cause medial rotation of the hip and knee joint, and 
biceps femoris causes lateral rotation of the hip and knee joint.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following muscles is not a part of the anterior compartment of the thigh?
questions.explanation:
1080 
Sold by @itachibot The gracilis muscle belongs to the medial compartment of the thigh. Muscles of the anterior compartment: • Sartorius • Rectus femoris • Vasti medialis, lateralis, and intermedius • Articularis genus Note: Adductor longus and pectineus are sometimes considered to be part of both the anterior and the 
medial compartments.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 30-year-old woman suddenly falls during her dance performance. She was rushed to the 
hospital by her friends. On examination her knee was swollen and her movements were 
restricted. On X-ray examination, lateral displacement of the patella was noted. The weakness 
of which of the following muscle is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The weakness of the vastus medialis is responsible for the lateral displacement of the patella. The lowest fibers of the vastus medialis muscle, which are attached medially to the upper half of 
the patella are referred to as vastus medialis obliquus. These fibers of the vastus medialis prevent 
the lateral displacement of the patella, during knee motion. The weakness of the vastus medialis 
obliquus may lead to patellar instability and pain.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following muscles cause medial rotation of the flexed knee?
questions.explanation:
Medial rotation of the flexed knee is produced by the following muscles: • Semimembranosus • Popliteus • Semitendinosus 1081 
Sold by @itachibot • Assisted by • Sartorius • Gracilis Knee joint is a complex synovial joint consisting of tibiofemoral and patellofemoral articulations. 
Movements occurring at knee joint are flexion, extension, medial rotation, and lateral rotation. • Flexion - biceps femoris, semitendinosus, and semimembranosus (hamstrings) • Extension - quadriceps femoris, assisted by tensor fasciae latae • Medial rotation of the flexed leg - popliteus, semimembranosus, and semitendinosus • Lateral rotation of the flexed leg - biceps femoris Note: Semimembranosus tendinopathy may develop as a result of the overuse of muscle usually 
cyclists and marathon runners. Patients may complain of insidious pain in the posteromedial part 
of the knee radiating distally to the medial calf or proximally to the posteromedial thigh. It is a 
cause of chronic knee pain that often goes undiagnosed as it is poorly understood.

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient presents the OPD with complaints of acute pain and swelling over the dorsum of 
her right midfoot. On examination, tenderness was present and the resisted dorsiflexion test 1064 
Sold by @itachibot for the great toe was positive. The muscle affected is innervated by which nerve?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, the muscle likely to be affected is extensor hallucis longus, which is 
innervated by the deep peroneal nerve.

questions.question: Question 18: The anterior compartment of the leg contains all of the following muscles except:
questions.explanation:
Peroneus brevis muscle belongs to the lateral compartment of the leg. Muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg produce dorsiflexion (extension) of the ankle. 
They are: • Extensor digitorum longus • Extensor hallucis longus • Tibialis anterior • Peroneus tertius (inverts and everts foot) Muscles of the posterior compartment produce plantar flexion. They include superficial and deep 
groups which are separated by the transverse intermuscular septum. • The superficial flexor group consists of the gastrocnemius, plantaris, and soleus. • The deep flexor group consists of popliteus, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, and 
tibialis posterior. Muscles of lateral compartment evert the ankle and include peroneus longus and peroneus brevis. 1082 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: Which muscle is not involved in the inversion of foot?
questions.explanation:
Peroneus longus muscle is not involved in the inversion of the foot. It causes eversion and plantar 
flexion. Inversion of the foot is a movement in which the medial border of the foot is elevated so that the 
sole faces medially. • Tibialis anterior - Causes dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot • Tibialis posterior - Causes plantar flexion and inversion of the foot • Extensor hallucis longus - Causes extension of the great toe, dorsiflexion of the foot, and 
inversion of the foot (minimal action) 1083 
Sold by @itachibot Eversion of the foot is a movement where the lateral border of the foot is elevated so that the sole 
faces laterally. Peroneus longus, peroneus brevis, and peroneus tertius are the muscles involved. These movements take place, mainly at the talocalcaneal and the talocalcaneonavicular joints, and 
partly at the transverse tarsal joint.

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient with weakness of leg is not able to perform the movement shown in the image. 
Which muscle weakness causes loss of this movement? 1065 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The action shown in the image is plantar flexion of the ankle joint and weakness of gastrocnemius 
muscle causes loss of this movement. The plantar flexion of the toe is produced mainly by gastrocnemius and soleus, assisted by 
plantaris, tibialis posterior, flexor hallucis longus, and flexor digitorum longus. Dorsiflexion is caused by the tibialis anterior and assisted by extensor digitorum longus, extensor 
hallucis longus, and peroneus tertius. 1084 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following muscles is known as triceps surae?
questions.explanation:
The gastrocnemius (two heads) and soleus muscles are collectively known as triceps surae. 
They constitute a powerful muscular mass whose main function is plantar flexion of the foot. The main bulk of the calf is formed by gastrocnemius, plantaris, and soleus muscles. These 3 
muscles form the superficial flexor group of the posterior compartment of the lower leg.

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following passive movements causes pain in a patient suffering from deep 
posterior compartment syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Dorsiflexion of the foot causes pain in the deep posterior compartment syndrome of the leg. All tibial fractures should be monitored for signs of compartment syndrome. Severe pain is the 
most important clinical feature. Regular clinical evaluation is important because swelling, 
blistering, and skin necrosis is associated with late, severe compartment syndrome. Compartment syndromes of the lower limb: • Superficial and deep posterior compartment syndrome - There will be pain on passive 
dorsiflexion of the foot and on the toe extension • Anterior compartment syndrome - There will be pain on passive plantar flexion of the foot and 
toe flexion • Lateral compartment syndrome - There will be pain on passive foot inversion.

questions.question: Question 23: The first layer of the sole consists of:
questions.explanation:
1085 
Sold by @itachibot The first layer of the sole consists of abductor hallucis. The muscles of the sole of the foot are arranged in 4 layers. From superficial to deep, the layers 
are numbered from one to four. Muscles of the sole of the foot are: 1st layer: This is the superficial layer which includes abductor hallucis, abductor digiti minimi, 
and flexor digitorum brevis. 2nd layer: It consists of flexor accessorius and the four lumbrical muscles,the tendons of flexor 
hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus run in the same plane as the muscles of the second 
layer. 3rd layer: It contains the shorter intrinsic muscles of the toes, which are flexor hallucis brevis, 
adductor hallucis and flexor digiti minimi brevis. 1086 
Sold by @itachibot 4th layer: It consists of plantar and dorsal interossei and the tendons of tibialis posterior and 
fibularis longus. 1087 
Sold by @itachibot Nerves & Vessels of Lower Limb
